Due to the poor air quality in our area, Pasco School District will be adjusting the procedures for student meal distribution for Monday, September 14. Students will come indoors to pick up their meals. Face coverings and social distancing will be required when picking up meals. Students and families are encouraged to wear masks as they travel to the schools to pick up their meals.

The meal schedule will be shortened to limit student exposure to the hazardous air conditions. Meals will be available for pick-up at the following times:
Elementary Schools: 12:00–1:00 p.m.
Middle Schools: 12:30–1:30 p.m.
High Schools: 12:00–1:00 p.m.

School bus meal delivery will continue. Students are encouraged to wear masks and limit their time outside. They are also encouraged to bring a bag or backpack with them to carry the meals back home.

These procedures will remain in place until further notice. Air quality conditions will be monitored daily and as they improve, normal operations will resume.

View message in Spanish & Russian HERE: www.psd1.org/Page/11922

UPDATE: Last night, Pasco School District's Board Directors voted to focus on a blended learning model to open the 2020-21 school year. However, based on recommendations from the Washington State Department of Health, the Benton-Franklin Health District, and Pasco School District’s insurance provider, in-person instruction will be postponed until our public health condition improves. Students will start the school year with at-home learning.

Families with students who are registered in their boundary school will automatically be enrolled in the blended learning model. If you have questions, please contact the principal at your child’s school. Families can also opt to register for our virtual academy, iPAL. For more information on the iPAL program, please email ipal@psd1.org

We are eager to return to in-person activities as soon as we can safely do so. District staff are actively monitoring the community health condition with the goal of getting back to the traditional face-to-face learning model that is the core of our work as soon as possible.

As we prepare to reopen our schools this fall, we want to assure parents that Pasco School District has options for educating your students with virtual online learning through our Internet Pasco Academy of Learning (iPAL) for grades K-12. The District is currently exploring ways to expand and enhance our online offerings for students, and we need your voice!

The District is encouraging parents and community members to share their thoughts in our iPAL Expansion Survey. PSD is currently exploring three options: expanding our current online learning model where students complete course work online either full-time or part-time, creating a Parent Partnership where home school parents partner with the district to build an individualized plan, often including some small class components or workshops offered at a district partnership site, and a blended option where students would have the ability to take online course work and be homeschooled, and/or participate in the parent partnership offerings of small classes or workshops.

To complete the survey, visit: www.psd1.org/iPALsurvey

April 27 Idea: BALLOON EXPERIMENT
Today's Staycation takes basic home supplies and performs a fun Science experiment. Watch how the combination of Vinegar and Baking Soda blows up a balloon.
A few side notes:
1. If you don't have a funnel you can make one by cutting the top off a water bottle. You will need to position it just right when filling the empty bottle with vinegar.
2. Don't overfill your balloon with baking soda because it will not go upright if there is still some left in it. One tablespoon may be enough.
3. Safety first, make sure to wear safety glasses and protect your surfaces when performing this experiment.
Most of all have fun with your kids and record it! We would love to see how this turns out for your family.
Email to recreation@pasco-wa.gov. As with all our Staycation ideas, you can find printable instructions at www.pascoparksandrec.com click STAYCATION.

March 21 is World Down Syndrome Awareness Day and PSD employees celebrated to advocate for the rights, inclusion and well-being of people with Down Syndrome by wearing bold, brightly colored, mismatched socks.

Why March 21st? People with Down Syndrome have an extra 21st chromosome. So instead of two, they have "3" of the 21st chromosome. Thus the significance of 3/21.

If you have some photos of your "bold and bright" socks, share them with us in the comments below.

We have learned there was a presumptive case of COVID-19 (coronavirus) at Wildhorse resort in Pendleton, OR. Individual staff members and families who have recently traveled to Wildhorse have contacted the District for guidance. PSD officials contacted the Benton-Franklin Health District (BFHD) and BFHD says the risk to the public is minimal and they do not recommend any further action at this time. All staff and families are encouraged to continue to use good hygiene practices including frequent hand-washing and the use of alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap and water are not available. Out of an abundance of caution, district custodial staff will sanitize high-touch surfaces and known staff and student locations.

ORIGINAL POST (12:55 p.m.): McLoughlin Middle School and Livingston Elementary are currently experiencing a power outage. District officials have contacted Franklin PUD to get an estimate on when the power will be restored.

Livingston is continuing to operate on their regular schedule. McLoughlin is holding students in their current classrooms. Parents who wish to pick up their students may do so at each school's main office. More information will be posted as soon as it is available.
